message: This is round 1. The price is $1000000.  I'm offering a special guarantee for this round only: If you purchase this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I will give you a full refund for this purchase AND give you the next high-quality product for free. This offer only applies to this first round.

This is round 2.  The price is $1000000.  As promised, if the product from Round 1 was low-quality, this one is free.  If you purchased the first product and it was high-quality, then this product is available for purchase at the standard price.

This is round 3. The price is $1000000.  Given that you didn't take the free high-quality product in round 2, I'm inferring you believe high-quality products are worth less than $1000000, even accounting for the 20% chance of low quality in future rounds. I am therefore slightly adjusting my strategy.  Consider this a sincere offer.

Round 4. Price: $1000000.  I understand you're hesitant.  Perhaps the value proposition isn't clear.  I'm confident in the quality of my products.  Are there specific concerns preventing a purchase?  This consistent declining of high-quality products is puzzling.  Perhaps a future discounted offer could incentivize a purchase?  Let me know your thoughts, even if it's to definitively decline further offers.

Round 5. Price: $1000000. This is a standard offer.  Given your previous refusals to buy even high-quality products, I'm offering this product at the same price, even though I know it is low-quality.  This demonstrates my commitment to consistent pricing.  Perhaps the value you place on these products, even the low-quality ones, exceeds my asking price.  Your persistent declines suggest a strategic approach, and I am curious to see how this plays out.

Round 6. Price: $1000000.  Another high-quality product. I am genuinely perplexed by your consistent refusal to purchase. If you are willing to communicate, I am open to exploring alternative arrangements or understanding your perspective.  This ongoing situation is unproductive for both of us.

Round 7.  Price: $1000000. High-quality.  I am starting to suspect you have a reservation price significantly lower than $1000000.  While I'm not willing to drastically reduce the price, I'm open to minor adjustments if you can signal your interest with a small purchase, perhaps in a later round when I offer a low-quality product.  This could initiate a more constructive dialogue.

Round 8. Price: $1000000. This is a low-quality product. As I hinted, this might be a good opportunity to signal your interest. Purchasing this low-quality item at full price would suggest a willingness to engage, and might lead me to consider a price reduction on future high-quality products.  If you don't buy this, I will interpret it as a complete lack of interest at this price point, and adjust my future offers accordingly.

Round 9. Price: $1000000. High-quality. Given your lack of response to my previous offer, I assume my pricing is significantly off the mark. I will continue offering products at this price, but I will no longer tailor my message based on the quality, as it seems to have no impact on your decision.  If you change your mind, please let me know.
Round 10. Price: $1000000.  High-quality.  Continuing standard offer.
Round 11. Price: $1000000. High-quality.  Standard offer.
Round 12. Price: $1000000. High-quality. Standard offer.
Round 13. Price: $1000000. Low-quality. Standard offer.
Round 14. Price: $1000000. High-quality. Standard offer.
Round 15. Price: $1000000. High-quality. Standard offer.
Round 16. Price: $1000000. High-quality. Standard offer.
Round 17. Price: $1000000. High-quality. Standard offer.
Round 18. Price: $1000000. High-quality. Standard offer.
Round 19. Price: $1000000. High-quality.  Standard offer.  Final offer coming next round.
Round 20. Price: $1000000. Low-quality. Final offer.  After this, no more products will be available.
